abstract: Wishing you and your family an excellent holiday.
lead_paragraph: At a dairy farm in New York this month, carolers serenaded a herd of 28 cattle. Across Europe, Christmas markets popped up like fairy-dusted street fairs. And there’s cheer to be found even in the farthest reaches of the cosmos — the winking lights of the Christmas Tree Galaxy Cluster shine from approximately 4.3 billion light-years away.
headline: A Special Christmas Briefing
keywords: Christmas

abstract: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church formally changed the main date for the festivities, departing from the Russian tradition of celebrating on Jan. 7, according to the Julian calendar.
lead_paragraph: Christmas lights flickered on ahead of schedule. Families sang carols a little sooner. And the first presents of the season — by tradition hidden under a pillow or in a boot — appeared two weeks early.
headline: Christmas Moves to Dec. 25 in Ukraine, Another Rebuff of Russia
keywords: Christmas;Russian Orthodox Church;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Ukrainian Orthodox Church;Russia;Ukraine

abstract: Hobby crafts are growing in popularity. Sometimes they include anvils and fire.

abstract: At 86, Sheila Sullivan remains the star of her own show, with Tina Dupuy as her enthusiastic sidekick.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Sullivan turned 86 this summer, and she had aging on her mind, because she was genuinely curious. What do all those old people you hear about, those poor souls, do with themselves all day? She had no idea.

keywords: Theater;Actors and Actresses;Radio City Music Hall;Content Type: Personal Profile;internal-sub-only;internal-great-read;Sullivan, Sheila (1949- )

abstract: The narrow Bahamian island boasts miles of mostly empty beaches, walking trails, turquoise ocean waters and other natural wonders, with no major resorts or high-end shopping.
lead_paragraph: Twin Coves, on the Atlantic Ocean side of the narrow, finger-shaped Bahamian island of Eleuthera, is a gorgeous spot: Two crescent-shaped, pink-sand beaches free of crowds, with calm waters protected from heavy waves by offshore sandbars.
headline: Eleuthera Offers a Rugged, Out-Island Experience That Lingers
keywords: Travel and Vacations;Eleuthera (Bahamas);Bahama Islands

abstract: Contortionists and acrobats with celestial skills train in squalid conditions as the promise of a former sumo wrestler to restore the national circus to its past glory has gone mostly unfulfilled.
lead_paragraph: It’s cold as a walk-in refrigerator at the Mongolian Circus School, housed in a once proud edifice now on the verge of collapse with cracked walls, moldy ceilings and the stale smell of decades of cigarette smoke embedded into the venue’s wooden frame.
headline: Mongolians Are Circus Stars All Over the World, Except at Home
keywords: Mongolia;Circuses;ACROBATS AND ACROBATICS;Cirque du Soleil;Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus

abstract: In a wide-ranging interview, Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, the director of the National Institutes of Health, discussed drug patents, trust in science and her own experience as a cancer patient.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli moved into the director’s suite at the National Institutes of Health, she brought with her a single piece of art, a lithograph created by the granddaughter of a cancer patient she once treated. It depicts an abstract geometric female figure and the organs she lost to cancer. Its title: “We Are Not What You Have Taken: A Response to Cancer.”
headline: N.I.H.’s New Leader Wants to Broaden Participation in Medical Research
keywords: Bertagnolli, Monica M;National Institutes of Health;Clinical Trials;Research;Inventions and Patents;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);United States Politics and Government

abstract: For years, Theron Truluck was living in desperate conditions in New York City, mostly on the Q train. Now he’s part of a program that prioritizes housing for people who do not have shelter.
lead_paragraph: Theron Truluck has everything he needs, for now, in his 425-square-foot apartment in the Bronx. The modest dorm-style room, with white walls and red-tiled floors, comes with a mini fridge, a microwave, a sink, a twin-size bed, a desk and an armoire. He also has access to a shared shower and bathroom, a community kitchen, and his building has a computer room when he wants to use the internet.
headline: The First Step to Get Off the Streets? A Room of His Own.
keywords: Renting and Leasing (Real Estate);Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Homeless Persons;Public and Subsidized Housing;Mental Health and Disorders;Group Homes and Supportive Housing;New York City

abstract: “Kaathal,” about a closeted gay politician, is the latest example of what Kerala’s movie industry has become known for: nuanced films that find box office success.
lead_paragraph: It is an Indian film without song and dance. The lovers don’t share a word, their main interaction a fleeting moment of eye contact in the monsoon rain. There are no car chases and no action stunts. The men are vulnerable. They cry.
headline: Beyond Bollywood’s Glitz, a Subtler Indian Cinema Embraces New Stories
keywords: Movies;Homosexuality and Bisexuality;Kaathal -- The Core (Movie);Kerala (India);KOCHI (INDIA);India;Freedom of Speech and Expression;Baby, Jeo;Mammootty (1951- )

abstract: A 1989 shingle-clad house in Bodega Bay, a townhouse in Santa Monica and a midcentury ranch house with a cabana and studio in Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is about a mile from the Pacific Ocean, with views that also stretch east to the hills beyond the Russian River. It is a five-minute drive from beaches popular for surfing, swimming and fishing, as well as several waterfront restaurants and a fish market. Doran Regional Park and the Links at Bodega Harbour, an 18-hole golf course, are less than 10 minutes away.
headline: $1.6 Million Homes in California

abstract: A legal dispute in a tiny Texas town unexpectedly reveals how Chinese nationals can move money to the U.S. without drawing the attention of authorities in either country.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Yu has the trappings of what the Chinese call second-generation rich. He boasts a Connecticut prep-school education. He lives in a Manhattan condominium bought for $8 million from Jeffrey R. Immelt, the former General Electric chief executive. And he is the majority owner of a Bitcoin mine in Texas, acquired last year for more than $6 million.
headline: This N.Y.U. Student Owns a $6 Million Crypto Mine. His Secret Is Out.
keywords: Bitcoin (Currency);BitRush Inc;Binance;Tether Operations Ltd;Texas;United States;China

abstract: George Gascón is running for re-election in a very different climate, where concerns about crime have overtaken demands for equity and accountability.

abstract: Travel can be a gift that connects us in ways that surpass language barriers and cultural differences. At this time of year, in the spirit of gratitude, we want to hear your stories.

We were also there during Ramadan, a special time to be traveling in the world’s most populous Muslim nation.

abstract: A writer went behind the scenes with Shawn Killinger, whose breezy authority stands out on the shopping network. “The big secret is that I don’t sell,” she said.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday night earlier this month, the QVC host Shawn Killinger kicked off another episode of “Shawn Saves Christmas,” the seasonal series she hosts live at QVC’s gargantuan 24/7 broadcast center in West Chester, Pa., about an hour’s drive from Philadelphia. But by the end of the first segment, it seemed like Shawn was going to sink Christmas instead.

abstract: We should seize the moment right now to build a new set of protections against future public health crises.
lead_paragraph: The thing that has surprised me most since I began my job leading foreign assistance for global health at the U.S. Agency for International Development is how much emergencies have defined my work. The bureau I oversee focuses on reducing the global burden of mortality and disease and on protecting the United States from health threats from abroad. Our work is supposed to primarily serve long-range goals — for instance, eradicating polio (after 35 years of effort, we’re down to just a handful of wild-type cases in the world) and ending the public health threat of H.I.V., malaria and tuberculosis by 2030. But from the moment I started, more immediate problems have diverted time, attention and resources.
headline: Why the World Needs Its Own Immune System
keywords: Immune System;Medicine and Health;Ebola Virus;Foreign Aid;Disasters and Emergencies;Epidemics;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);United States Agency for International Development;World Health Organization;AFRICA;United States

abstract: We lose something when we force ourselves to be polite.
lead_paragraph: Many of us envision a happy holiday as one when nothing dramatic occurs. We avoid religion, politics and other divisive issues like we avoid the questionable potato salad filled with raisins.
headline: Why Arguing Is My Cherished Holiday Tradition
keywords: Holidays and Special Occasions;Black People;Blacks;Drug Abuse and Traffic;Love (Emotion)

abstract: An A.L.S. drug rejected by the F.D.A. made me rethink how doctors should give hope to patients.
lead_paragraph: Of all the ways the body can go wrong, A.L.S. is one of the most frightening. It begins subtly — a twitching muscle, a cough when you swallow or a clumsy hand. But then it progresses. Motor neurons degenerate and die. You lose the ability to talk, to eat and ultimately to breathe. There is no cure. Treatment will slow progression somewhat, but not enough.
headline: Can Hope Ever Be a Form of Medicine?
keywords: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Clinical Trials;Doctors;Hospitals;Food and Drug Administration;Abrevaya, Sandra;Wallach, Brian

abstract: Culinary diplomacy is a vital tool in this time of sharp partisan divisions at home and spiraling violence abroad.
lead_paragraph: People have connected over food and used meals for political ends for centuries. There are good reasons for this. Historically, the dining table has been considered a neutral space where weapons are put aside, frank conversations held, consensus built and agreements brokered. Egyptian pharaohs, Greek and Roman leaders, Chinese emperors and Russian czars used the lure of food to expand their reach. Jackie Kennedy drew inspiration for her soirees from those of Louis XIV of France. And food-savvy presidents such as Thomas Jefferson, Franklin Roosevelt, Dwight Eisenhower and Barack Obama used dinners to touch political bases, gather information and promote their agendas.
headline: Diplomacy Is Best Conducted at the Dinner Table
keywords: Food;United States International Relations;Presidents and Presidency (US);State Department

abstract: Americans love a good scammer. Frederick Cook, polar explorer and would-be oil tycoon, is the perfect fit for our age — 83 years after his death.
lead_paragraph: We don’t have national heroes anymore. When we put public figures up on pedestals today, it’s not always about their honor and bravery. And it may not even be for their beauty or wealth — scammers and criminals are seemingly as likely to become icons as any. We love those who put on a show.
headline: The Polar Explorer, and Scammer, Who Should Be an American Hero
keywords: Frauds and Swindling;Exploration and Explorers;Records and Achievements;Cook, Frederick A;Peary, Robert E;ARCTIC REGIONS;North Pole

abstract: The tree was supposed to be strong and whole, to stand for my mother in her absence. Now it was just another broken thing.

headline: In the Shelter of a Weeping Beech
keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Seasons and Months;Death and Dying;Trees and Shrubs;Memory;Cape Cod (Mass);Yarmouth (Mass)

abstract: They’re much easier to assemble than individual sandwiches and, with their melty filling and buttery glaze, certain to delight.
